title: Why do some people like sad stories? - Quora

response.answer_text: Part of the reason is what psychologists call identification. Most humans have empathy for others, it’s part of our psychological makeup as social creatures. We can imagine how others feel because we know how WE would feel under the same or similar circumstances. That is identification in a nutshell. On an unconscious level it reminds us that deep down inside we’re all the same, that feeling sadness is part of the shared human condition, we can *identify* (sympathize) with others. Logic doesn’t really apply to human emotions, but it certainly is reasonable behavior. From an anthropological viewpoint, this empathy (identification, sympathizing) would bond together members of a tribe, which typically would have around 50 people. Sociological studies show that, even in modern crowded urban and city settings, most people have around 50 others (friends and co-workers) that they associate with on a regular basis—their “tribe”. So, sad stories, movies and songs, reinforce that feeling of “belonging” that is part of our evolutionary heritage as social animals.

Emotions are chemical reactions in the body that create intense experience, much like a narcotic, only generated from within. Just like one can get addicted to the effect of a drug, one can get addicted to the effect of the chemical reactions generated from emotions. Some people seek external catalysts for this emotion so they can get their fix. Sadness, fear, empathy, exhilaration - most emotions have a corresponding genres in film for each type of addict.
